title: 112_hr3191
content:
The Act is titled the "John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park Establishment Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park is established to preserve and interpret the industrial heritage of the region for future generations. It aims to protect the landscape features and educate the public about the industrial history and significance of the National Heritage Corridor. The National Heritage Corridor is significant for its past and present importance. Partners are encouraged to protect, improve, and manage key resources within the corridor. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Map - Refers to the map titled "John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park", dated October 2011.
(2) National heritage corridor - Refers to the John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor.
(3) Park - Refers to the John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park established under section 4.
(4) Secretary - Refers to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service.
(5) State - Refers to the States of Massachusetts and Rhode Island.

SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF JOHN H. CHAFEE BLACKSTONE RIVER VALLEY NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK. The John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park is established in the States, comprising various historic districts and sites, including the Old Slater Mill National Historic Landmark District, Slatersville Historic District, Ashton Historic District, Whitinsville Historic District, Hopedale Village Historic District, Blackstone River, Blackstone Canal. The map of the Park is available for public inspection, and the Secretary may acquire land within the Park boundaries through donation. Interests in land within the Park can be acquired by donation, purchase with funds, or exchange. The Secretary administers the Park according to applicable laws and cooperative agreements, including a general management plan within 3 years of funding availability. The Secretary must prepare a general management plan for the Park in consultation with the States and in accordance with cooperative agreements and relevant laws. The plan should consider utilizing existing and planned facilities in the National Heritage Corridor. The National Heritage Corridor includes various visitor centers and parks in Rhode Island and Massachusetts, with the Secretary able to enter cooperative agreements with different entities for management. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for resource protection activities in the National Heritage Corridor, in cooperation with various entities.
